title: How to Cool Yourself Down on a Hot Day

steps.headline: Wear clothes that will keep you cool.
steps.description: Linen and cotton are good fabrics for a hot day. Loose clothes are generally better for keeping cool over tight, close-fitting ones, so consider flowing garments. Don't tuck everything in and button everything up.

steps.headline: Cover your skin.
steps.description: Long-sleeved shirts made of cotton, hemp and other natural fabrics will help deflect the sun's rays and protect your skin.

steps.headline: Wear a hat.
steps.description: A broad-brimmed hat is essential to protect your face and to create some shade over your head.

steps.headline: Wear a sarong, for men and women.
steps.description: Pair with shirts, skirts, shorts, Capri pants and trousers. You don't have to show your legs off to keep cool or be cool. For both sexes, you might feel cooler in lighter colors, such as white, pale blue, light green, stone, etc.

steps.headline: Keep your feet cool too.
steps.description: Consider wearing sandals that match your outfit. You can even put on some black and white pumps or flats. Flip-flops or sandals are great too. Go barefoot for really cool feet, but be wary about walking on hot surfaces like sand. Avoid boots, obviously!

steps.headline: Apply lots of sunscreen throughout the day.
steps.description: The protective function of such lotion only lasts for a few hours and less when you are in water. Reapply frequently for best coverage. Do not rely on it alone, however. Always combine with wearing a hat, long-sleeved clothing and keeping out of the sun during the hottest part of the day.

steps.headline: Drink lots of water to regain the water lost due to sweating.
steps.description: Then try drinking a refreshing fruit smoothie.

steps.headline: Keep still and quiet.
steps.description: This is not a good time for exercising, sports or running around. Keep these activities for the evening when the air becomes cooler and the sun goes down. Slow the heart rate down first by taking deep breaths. This will be calming and can cool the body.

steps.headline: Have a cold shower or bath.
steps.description: Even a small amount of water sprayed or splashed on you can help. Or try a face washer dipped in cold water and held against your face and forehead for instant cooling relief. Wet towels if you need to cool all of your body and wrap your legs, torso and arms with them. Stand or sit in your bath and run the shower over your body and you should feel much cooler.

steps.headline: Wet parts of your body.
Use ice.
steps.description:
Get a bag of ice. Put it on your forehead for 30 minutes. Chew on ice cubes. steps.headline: Keep inside or in the shade when the sun is at its height.
steps.description: Don't go outside if you can help it between 11 o'clock and 3 o'clock, as these are the hours during which the sun is at its strongest.

steps.headline: Try to get used to the heat.
steps.description: Try to do this without relying on fans too much. That way, you can be more independent of relying on any electrical equipment. This can become very important should there be a summer blackout.

steps.headline: Open the windows to let in a breeze.
steps.description: Use screens to keep out insects if they are a problem.

steps.headline: Use fans.
steps.description: Fans keep the air circulating and produce a small cooling effect. Place a wet face cloth on the fan to produce a mini air-conditioning effect. Be careful to set the wet cloth only on the outer cage part of the fan so that it cannot be caught by the fan blades. Also do not leave the room without removing the cloth from the fan.

steps.headline: Stay in the shade.
steps.description: Read a good book, sit still or take a nap. When you move around, you will get hotter and hotter.

steps.headline: Go swimming.
steps.description: If you can, select a shady body of water.

steps.headline: Play with water.
Repeatedly spray yourself with cold water from a spray bottle.
steps.description: It keeps you cool and feels good.
